Context:
The text is about a Bachelor's degree program in American Sign Language-English Interpretation offered by the college. The program lasts for four years and focuses on seven areas of learning: language and culture, field fundamentals, interpreting skills, research methods/trends, ethics and professionalism, breadth electives, and field and community experience. Students with a diploma or advanced diploma in American Sign Language-English interpretation can apply for an advanced entry option. The program aims to develop interpreters who are critical thinkers with unbiased communicative language and interpreting practices and an understanding of how intersectionality shapes interactions, using an anti-oppressive framework situated through Deaf-centric foundations.

To be a successful interpreter, one needs a strong command of both English and American Sign Language, an excellent memory, the ability to concentrate and focus for long periods, quick cognitive processing skills, multitasking abilities, versatility, flexibility, strong communication skills, and excellent interpersonal skills. Students will participate in field placement experiences and work in various group settings.

There is an option for a 420-hour internship experience as part of the field education. Applicants with questions should download and fill out the C302 Applicant Questionnaire.
file_path: scraped_pages/programpages2023/Honours Bachelor of Interpretation (American Sign Language – English) Program C302 | George Brown College2023.txt

Context: The Honours Bachelor of Interpretation (ASL – English) program at George Brown College requires students to complete a senior internship of approximately 420 hours (equivalent to 14 weeks) in the fall semester of their fourth year. This unpaid field experience provides an opportunity for students to apply their skills and knowledge in various environments under the supervision of a professional interpreter, gain understanding of community agencies and partnership opportunities for sign language interpreters, and engage in research. Additionally, fourth-year students offer limited pro bono interpreting services through the Volunteer Student Interpreting Services (GBC-VSIS). Graduates of the program can find employment opportunities as ASL-English interpreters or Deaf interpreters in various sectors such as educational settings, medical settings, legal contexts, business interactions, and social service agencies. Possible job titles include Deaf interpreter, ASL-English interpreter, designated interpreter, ASL consultant, conference interpreter, community interpreter, and translator. The degree can serve as a pathway to these careers in both private and public environments.
file_path: scraped_pages/programpages2023/Honours Bachelor of Interpretation (American Sign Language – English) Program C302 | George Brown College2023.txt

Context: The text provides information about a degree program in Interpreting Studies offered by the college. The program includes courses taken during Semesters 1 through 8. Each semester has specific required courses with their respective codes and names, such as American Sign Language I (BINT 1001) and Introduction to the Interpreting Profession (BINT 1004). Students are also required to select one Liberal Studies Elective for each semester, except for Semesters 5, 7, and 8. Some of the courses include Deaf Studies, Cognitive Processing Skills, Sociolinguistics for Interpreters, Values, Ethics and Professional Practice, and Introduction to Translation and Discourse Analysis. The program culminates with an unpaid internship experience (420 Hours) during Semester 8. There are also courses related to interpreting interaction, community interpreting, and interpreting practices. Some courses have names such as Interpreting Practicum Field I and Interpreting Practicum Field II. The program offers various electives and courses on technology, collaborations, research in Interpreting Studies, and American Sign Language up to level VI.
file_path: scraped_pages/programpages2023/Honours Bachelor of Interpretation (American Sign Language – English) Program C302 | George Brown College2023.txt

Context:
SEMESTER 8 Courses:
- BINT 3101: Dynamics in the Deaf Community: Contrastive Analysis
- BINT 4002: Interpreting IV
- BINT 4104: Research in Interpreting Studies II
- One Liberal Studies Elective (selectable)

Program Learning Outcomes:
- Analyze and critically apply current interpreting research trends
- Analyze power dynamics that affect human communication
- Respect cross-cultural needs of participants in an interpreted interaction
- Articulate societal views of Deaf culture, Deaf community, multiculturalism, oppression, audism, global history of Deaf people, sign language linguistics and language variations
- Use current research literature to analyze key issues relating to interpreting practice and profession
- Determine appropriate modes of interpreting using evidence-based practice
- Perform effectively as an interpreter by incorporating current research and recognizing contextual factors
- Perform accurate and effective translations, consecutive and simultaneous interpretations
- Use communicative language abilities in first and second language as required
- Use professional and ethical judgment in decision-making
- Engage in lifelong learning and reflective professional development
- Assess personal competencies and limitations in multicultural and multi-contextual approaches to communication

Tuition & Fees:
- Domestic Tuition (Fall 2022): $8,414.00 *+
- International Tuition (Fall 2023): $20,445.00 **+
- Additional Costs: subject to change for programs starting in Fall 2023 and later dates

* Amount does not include cost of work experience
** Amount does not include cost of work experience

Financial Assistance: (Information can be found on the International Fees and Related Costs page)

Context:
The International Fees and Related Costs for this program can be found on the college's website. This program is approved for OSAP funding for applicants who meet OSAP eligibility criteria. Applicants need an Ontario Secondary School Diploma with a minimum combined average of 65% in six grade 12 university (U) or university/college (M) courses, including grade 12 English (U) with a minimum grade of 65%, and either grade 11 math (M or U), grade 12 math U, grade 11 science (U), or grade 12 science (M or U). Mature students must have the same English, math, and science credits and a combined average of 65% in English and math/science. Non-Deaf applicants require basic ASL proficiency level equivalent to approximately 200 hours of instruction and practical use. Deaf Interpreter applicants need advanced comprehension and articulation of American Sign Language, along with awareness of connotative levels of meaning, idiomatic expressions, and colloquialism use. All applicants must attend a mandatory information session, complete an applicant questionnaire, attend a mandatory in-person online screening session that evaluates ASL and pre-interpretation skills, submit a letter of reference during the screening session, and bring a set of earbuds or headphones for one assessment (not applicable for Deaf applicants). No specific program name was mentioned in the text.

Context:
The text provides information about the assessment process and requirements for applicants to a sign language interpreting program at George Brown College. Here are some key factual details extracted from the text:

* Applicants must demonstrate proficiency in American Sign Language (ASL) and pre-interpretation skills as part of the assessment process.
* Applicants are required to have an understanding of the Deaf community and the field of sign language interpreting.
* A letter of reference from a Deaf person is preferred, addressing the applicant's current ASL abilities, involvement in the Deaf community, and reasons for supporting their application.
* The competencies required can be acquired through George Brown's American Sign Language and Deaf Studies certificate program (C114) or an equivalent program.
* Applicants may be required to have grades/averages above the minimum.
* There is no admissions assessment for English, math, or science requirements.
* Advanced entry is available for graduates of George Brown's three-year American Sign Language – English interpreter advanced diploma program and graduates of other ASL-English interpreting diploma programs across Canada and the U.S. with specific academic achievements and completion of a screening interview.

No email or contact information was provided in the text.
file_path: scraped_pages/programpages2023/Honours Bachelor of Interpretation (American Sign Language – English) Program C302 | George Brown College2023.txt

Context:
Program Requirements:
- Minimum 3.0 GPA for Diploma Program
- Completion of Research Course with a minimum passing grade of 65%
- Completion of two Liberal Studies courses with a minimum passing grade of 65%
- Screening interview assessing ASL proficiencies and interpretation theory and skills
- English Language Proficiency: George Brown College ESL Level 9, TOEFL 84 overall and 21 in each skill band (online), IELTS 6.5 overall and 6.0 in each skill band, MELAB 85, CAEL overall 70 (writing 60)
- Course Exemptions: College or university credits may qualify for course exemptions. Visit Transfer Guide for more information.
- International Students: Visit International Admissions page for country-specific admission requirements.
- Police Reference Check required for all students in the program before field placement. Fees vary and it is student's responsibility to ensure the check covers appropriateness for "individuals being employed and/or volunteering who will be working with vulnerable person(s)". Students unable to provide a clear police reference check may be unable to complete their field placement and the program. Visit Pre-placement record check for more details.
- Our field placement partners may require students to show proof of vaccination. It is student's responsibility to ensure all pre-placement requirements are met.

How to Apply:
- Domestic students should apply through Ontario Colleges.
- International Students should visit the How to Apply page for more information on how and when to apply. They should also apply through George Brown College.

Context: International students should apply through the George Brown College Online Application System for the Honours Bachelor of Interpretation (American Sign Language – English) program. The contact email for the School of Deaf and Deafblind Studies is communityservices@georgebrown.ca, with office hours from 8 a.m. to 4 p.m. The Program Co-ordinators' emails are ckennedy@georgebrown.ca (Corene Kennedy) and rreynolds@georgebrown.ca (Rhondda Reynolds). For more information about George Brown College, contact their international recruitment representatives or visit the International Contact Us page. Related programs include American Sign Language and Deaf Studies (C114) and Deafblind & Intervenor Studies (C158). Nahed Dajjani shares that the professors are passionate about their work and provide tremendous support for students in this program. Potential applicants can book a campus tour or info session, sign up to receive tailored resources, and agree to receive email communications from George Brown College.
